key_points: The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground
A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform
Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary)
learning.explanation: The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground. A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform. Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary). Moreover, by detecting the drift due to the earth’s rotation, the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) will be able to internally calculate the True North. Latitude can also be internally calculated, but because this calculation is not sufficiently precise, a manual position input is required from the flight crew for this alignment sequence. Therefore, the system will compare the inserted latitude with the calculated one and compute precisely the aircraft’s position. On the other hand, the IRS cannot calculate/measure longitude, therefore the only reference is the one provided by the pilot during the alignment process.

key_points: The Inertial Navigation System (INS) receives data from three rate gyros, and two internal accelerometers measuring accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions
Accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions are measured by the accelerometers and are integrated
Acceleration integrated over time: Once = change in velocity
learning.explanation: The Inertial Navigation System (INS) receives data from three rate gyros, and two internal accelerometers measuring accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions. Accelerations in the East/West and North/South directions are measured by the accelerometers and are integrated. Acceleration integrated over time: Once = change in velocity. Twice = change in position. It is also true if we state that integrating velocity once over time gives the change in position. Internally, this is calculated by integrators that are time multiplication devices. Initially, acceleration is supplied to the integrator as a value in ft/sec². Multiplying a value in ft/sec² by another value in sec will give you a result in ft/sec => velocity. Velocity is basically how fast has the aircraft moved in feet per second. Then, this value is sent to another integrator to derive the change in position and determine the current position of the aircraft. In other words, a value in ft/sec is multiplied again by a value in seconds, which will result in a value in feet or NM => distance. The second integration will provide the IRS with the distance traveled, but if the initial position AND speed are known as well, the IRS will output the instantaneous position. Additional Input(s) Output ACCELERATION Once Initial SPEED Instantaneous SPEED ACCELERATION Once ----- Change in SPEED (velocity) ACCELERATION TWICE Initial POSITION + Initial SPEED Instantaneous POSITION ACCELERATION TWICE ----- POSITION SPEED ONCE ----- DISTANCE traveled

content.question:
The ring laser gyro uses which of the following?
1. A rotor and a gimbal system
2. A triangular glass block, also known as cervit glass
3. A cathode and an anode to excite the lasing medium
4. A rotor, optically driven by a single laser beam

options.A: 2 and 3
options.B: 1 and 4
options.C: 3 and 4
options.D: 1 and 2

key_points: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro
Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes
Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro
learning.explanation: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro. Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes. Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro. The RLG is produced from a block of a very stable glass ceramic compound, which has an extremely low coefficient of expansion. The triangular cavity contains a mixture of helium and neon gases at low pressure through which a current is passed. Lasing is achieved by running high voltages through helium neon gas between the anodes and the cathode transforming many of the atoms of the gas into light in the pinkish orange part of the visible spectrum (this action is helped by the tuned cavity effect of the tunnel in the glass block). The laser beam is forced to travel in both directions around the cavity. Thus, for a stationary block, the travelled paths are identical, and the frequencies of the two beams are the same at any sampling point. If the block is rotated, the effective path lengths differ; one increases, and the other decreases. Sampling at any point gives different frequencies, and if the frequency change is processed, it gives both an angular change, and a rate of angular change. By processing the difference in frequency between the two-pulsed light paths, the RLG is used as both a displacement, and as a rate gyro.

key_points: An INS uses a stabilised platform which must be aligned with the local horizontal and True North before it can be used in its navigation mode
When stationary the only output from the accelerometers will be due to gravity
During alignment the platform is driven by torque motors until no acceleration is sensed and is therefore level
learning.explanation: An INS uses a stabilised platform which must be aligned with the local horizontal and True North before it can be used in its navigation mode. When stationary the only output from the accelerometers will be due to gravity. During alignment the platform is driven by torque motors until no acceleration is sensed and is therefore level. Once level the platform has to be 'gyrocompassed' to align it with True North. This is acheived by monitoring the output of the gyros to sense topple caused by Earth rotation, the time taken to do this increases with latitude. For these reasons alignment can only be acheived if the aircraft is stationary. Moving an aircraft during alignment will require the process to start again when stationary and it could take as long as 15 - 20 minutes before alignment is complete. Pilots should always wait until INS alignment is complete before moving the aircraft

learning.explanation: Inertial Navigation means the determination of a vehicle’s location without the aid of external references. The Inertial Reference System (IRS) is a key component of an aircraft's inertial navigation system which is usually combined with a GPS receiver and sensor fusion software to show the flight crew where the plane is at any given moment even when GPS signals are not available. An IRS does not rely on conventional gyroscopes with masses spinning at high speeds (like INS). Instead, the system uses ring laser gyros (RLGs) that are attached to the aircraft structure in a specific orientation, and are therefore referred to as strapped-down. The coordinate system for computations is composed of the 3 aircraft axes. The IRS updates the aircraft's position by sensing its accelerations and integrating those movements with respect to time which establishes the direction of movement and distance from the start position. It is, therefore, independent of any externally generated (man-made) signals/visual references.

key_points: INS errors can be divided into two categories: bounded and unbounded errors
A bounded error will increase to its maximum and return to zero within 84
4 minutes Schuler cycle, while unbounded errors are cumulative track errors or distance errors (they are getting bigger and bigger with time)
learning.explanation: INS errors can be divided into two categories: bounded and unbounded errors. A bounded error will increase to its maximum and return to zero within 84.4 minutes Schuler cycle, while unbounded errors are cumulative track errors or distance errors (they are getting bigger and bigger with time). The question is asking how these unbounded errors are affecting the system over time since they are the only cumulative errors. In fact, they increase proportionally with time, which means that the error increases as ‘t’ increases. Bounded errors are usually the following: Initial misalignment may not be conducted 100% correctly (aircraft shaking due to ground equipment positioning, crew activity, etc.) There can always be some errors due to the initial misalignment. Accelerators are mechanical systems consisting of a pendulous mechanism, pickoffs and servos that suffer all from the standard instrument error (manufacturing imperfections). Integrators make errors in the first stage of integration due to the incorrect inputs provided (listed in the points above). Unbounded errors are usually the following: Initial azimuth misalignment of the platform. Drift of the gyroscopes of the platform, which are the main source of error.

The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information
learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. This system is composed of a stable platform consisting of high quality gyros and accelerometers and a computer. The purpose of the computer is to integrate the accelerometer outputs with time to give velocity and then integrate velocity with time to give distance travelled. From this is available pitch and roll attitude, true heading, true track, drift, present position in latitude and longitude, ground speed and wind. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. These acceleration measuring devices sense any change in the aircraft’s velocity either as an acceleration or deceleration very accurately. The acceleration signal from the amplifier is sent to an integrator which is a time multiplication device. It starts out with acceleration which is in feet per second squared. In the integrator, it is multiplied by time and the result is a velocity in feet per second. With an input of feet per second, it is then sent through a second integrator, which is multiplied by time, the result is a distance in feet or nautical miles. The computer associated with the inertial system knows the latitude and longitude of the take-off point and calculates that the aircraft has travelled so far in the north and east direction. The computer can then compute the new position of the aircraft and give a digital read-out.

learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Gyro-stabilised platforms are generally costly, heavy, and require a lengthy alignment procedure. With the introduction of relatively low cost, high-performance digital computers, these systems have been steadily replaced by mathematical computer software models, which modify the output signals from accelerometers that are strapped directly to the airframe. Referred to as an inertial reference system (IRS), it works on the same fundamental principles as the INS. The strap-down system dispenses with the gimbal mounted stable element and instead uses solid-state ring laser gyros (RLG). These gyros are not required to stabilise the accelerometers, as in the case of an INS, but provide aeroplane orientation, by determining the rate of rotation around each of the aeroplane axes. Input data is also required, such as the: TAS - to calculate the wind speed/direction. Initial position – because actual aircraft position during the flight is calculated based on the distance and direction flown from the initial reference position entered in the system. Barometric altitude – the platform can output the inertial height by itself, but its accuracy is insufficient for precise height control, hence the barometric altitude input. GNSS (GPS) Position - in order to bound the INS position error. Other inptus are: Mach Number, Radio height, Number of satellites and Angle of attack. Note: The correct option was selected according to EASA LO 022.05.01.01.02 which states 'State that inertial systems require no external input, except TAS, to determine aircraft attitude and navigational data.' learning.explanation: Inertial Navigation means the determination of a vehicle’s location without the aid of external references. An Inertial Reference System (IRS) is a more modern and advanced version of the traditional inertial navigation system (INS) used in aviation. The main difference between the two systems is that an IRS uses solid-state sensors, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) accelerometers and gyroscopes, instead of traditional mechanical gyroscopes and accelerometers. Some of the main advantages of the more modern IRS are: - The solid-state sensors are more reliable and require less maintenance compared to mechanical gyroscopes. They also provide higher accuracy and faster response times, resulting in more precise and smoother navigation. -It consists of three RLGs that measure angular rates and three internal accelerometers measuring acceleration on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). The laser gyros allow a microprocessor to maintain a stable platform mathematically, rather than mechanically. - The IRS can be integrated with other navigation systems, such as GPS or ground-based radio beacons, to provide even more accurate and reliable navigation information. - IRS systems also have the ability to compensate for various types of errors that may affect the accuracy of the navigation data. For example, errors caused by temperature changes, sensor drift, or other external factors.

content.question: How does an IRS work?

options.A: It consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate acceleration.
options.B: The IRS is located close to the aircraft C/G and it uses laser gyros to calculate angular rotations.
options.C: The IRS is located a bit away from the aircraft C/G and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations.
options.D: The IRS is most reliable using lower frequency laser beams.

key_points: An IRS does not rely on conventional gyroscopes with masses spinning at high speeds (like INS)
Instead, the system uses ring laser gyros (RLGs) that are attached to the aircraft structure in a specific orientation, and are therefore referred to as strapped-down
The coordinate system for computations is composed of the 3 aircraft axes
learning.explanation: An IRS does not rely on conventional gyroscopes with masses spinning at high speeds (like INS). Instead, the system uses ring laser gyros (RLGs) that are attached to the aircraft structure in a specific orientation, and are therefore referred to as strapped-down. The coordinate system for computations is composed of the 3 aircraft axes. The IRS uses 3 accelerometers and 3 RLGs that are installed at right angles to one another to measure linear accelerations and rotations around the aircraft axes. A high-performance computer creates a virtual stabilised platform that is kept aligned by using information from the gyros. Note that there is no physical platform that is kept aligned/level. In flight, the aircraft moves around the centre of gravity (CG). Placing the IRS unit close to the CG improves the reliability of the readings and reduces the amount of IRS drift experienced. RLGs produce two, constant, high-frequency beams of light that travel over a system of mirrors/through fibreoptics, in opposite directions. When the RLG is at rest, the signal from both beams is identical. When a RLG is rotated about its sensitive axis, both beams are affected by the Doppler effect. One is red shifted, and the other blue shifted. This causes a phase difference which can be interpreted by the computer to map motion. "The IRS is located a bit away from the aircraft CG and it uses laser gyros to calculate accelerations." INCORRECT. The laser gyros do not detect accelerations - accelerometers do that job. Furthermore, as stated above, it is located close to the CG of the aircraft. "It consists of gyros and accelerometers. The gyros keep the platform level and the accelerometers calculate acceleration." INCORRECT. The older stable-platform INS uses gyros and accelerometers on a level platform. "The IRS is most reliable using lower frequency laser beams." INCORRECT. Laser gyros use a high frequency excitation of the laser gas, not low frequency.

learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. LEVELLING AND ALIGNMENT For a conventional gyro system, the process of levelling and alignment takes approximately 15 to 20 minutes. It is important that the aeroplane does not move during this process, because the resultant accelerations upset the system, preventing the platform from aligning. This process also requires corrections to be applied, which are dependent on the system being ‘told’ the accurate value of the present latitude and longitude. The alignment process is unsuccessful if the wrong latitude is initially entered into the system; if the error is small, it leads to poor alignment and degraded accuracy. If the latitude error is large, the platform is unable to align. If the longitude is however wrongly inserted during the initialisation process, it does not adversely affect the alignment process, but will affect the accuracy of any subsequent position. This is because the INS is a direct reading system, and if you start with a wrong position all subsequent positions are wrong.

key_points: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro
Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes
Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro
learning.explanation: Solid-state gyros have no moving parts, but can achieve a significantly higher level of accuracy and serviceability than a conventional gyro. Unlike conventional gyros that maintain a level attitude by a series of gimbals, the RLG is fixed in orientation to the aeroplane axes. Any change in orientation, because of an aeroplane manoeuvre, is sensed by measuring the frequencies of two contra-rotating beams of light within the gyro. The RLG is produced from a block of a very stable glass ceramic compound, which has an extremely low coefficient of expansion. The triangular cavity contains a mixture of helium and neon gases at low pressure through which a current is passed. Lasing is achieved by running high voltages through helium neon gas between the anodes and the cathode transforming many of the atoms of the gas into light in the pinkish orange part of the visible spectrum (this action is helped by the tuned cavity effect of the tunnel in the glass block). The laser beam is forced to travel in both directions around the cavity. Thus, for a stationary block, the travelled paths are identical, and the frequencies of the two beams are the same at any sampling point. If the block is rotated, the effective path lengths differ; one increases, and the other decreases. Sampling at any point gives different frequencies, and if the frequency change is processed, it gives both an angular change, and a rate of angular change. By processing the difference in frequency between the two-pulsed light paths, the RLG is used as both a displacement, and as a rate gyro.

The main difference between the two systems is that an IRS uses solid-state sensors, such as Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) accelerometers and gyroscopes, instead of traditional mechanical gyroscopes and accelerometers. Some of the main advantages of the more modern IRS are: - The solid-state sensors are more reliable and require less maintenance compared to mechanical gyroscopes. They also provide higher accuracy and faster response times, resulting in more precise and smoother navigation - The IRS can be integrated with other navigation systems, such as GPS or ground-based radio beacons, to provide even more accurate and reliable navigation information. - IRS systems also have the ability to compensate for various types of errors that may affect the accuracy of the navigation data. For example, errors caused by temperature changes, sensor drift, or other external factors. While traditional INS systems using mechanical gyroscopes and stand-alone computers are still in use in many aircraft today, IRS systems offer several advantages over their predecessors, including higher accuracy, faster response times, and better reliability.

It is a very accurate system to measure rotation about a given axis and is widespread in modern commercial aircraft IRS systems
learning.explanation: The ring laser gyro (RLG) is a modern, more sophisticated alternative to the conventional gyroscope. It is used for the aircraft inertial navigation systems and attitude/heading reference systems. It is a very accurate system to measure rotation about a given axis and is widespread in modern commercial aircraft IRS systems. Conventional gyro’s rotation mass is replaced by two contra-rotating beams of light. The case of the RLG is made of a vitreous ceramic material of low-temperature coefficient. Two gas-tight openings are carefully designed into the single-piece case of the RLG, which are then filled with inert gas, such as a mixture of Helium and Neon. A direct current electrical discharge ionizes the gas and creates two beams of light flowing in opposite directions in the two cavities of the RLG case. In order to produce a continuous laser circuit in the enclosed area of the RLG’s case, a set of mirrors is installed to reflect and trap the laser beams. The frequency of oscillation of each beam depends on the optical path length and corresponds to the cavity resonance condition. When the RLG is stationary, both optical path lengths of each beam are identical. However, when the RLG is rotated about the axis perpendicular to the laser beams plane, one beam will travel a larger distance, and the other will cover a shorter distance. The frequency difference induced by different path lengths is proportional to the rotation rate.

learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Gyro-stabilised platforms are generally costly, heavy, and require a lengthy alignment procedure. With the introduction of relatively low cost, high-performance digital computers, these systems have been steadily replaced by mathematical computer software models, which modify the output signals from accelerometers that are strapped directly to the airframe. Referred to as an inertial reference system (IRS), it works on the same fundamental principles as the INS. The strap-down system dispenses with the gimbal mounted stable element and instead uses solid-state ring laser gyros (RLG). These gyros are not required to stabilise the accelerometers, as in the case of an INS, but provide aeroplane orientation, by determining the rate of rotation around each of the aeroplane axes.

learning.explanation: The Inertial Navigation System is a self-contained system that can provide continuous information on the aircraft's position, track, heading, groundspeed and, if necessary, height without any external assistance. Most aircraft of any size will be fitted with at least two inertial systems. The duplication is for redundancy and so that the information can be compared for possible error. The starting point for an inertial navigation system is acceleration. If acceleration is known, then the aircraft's speed can be calculated. If the speed is known, the distance travelled can be calculated. To solve a complete navigation problem in space, we need to know the acceleration in three axes at right angles to each other. The inertial system relates its acceleration to the three axes and recognizes the direction, using three methods: Stable Platform or Stabilised Inertial Platform Wander Angle Strapdown The Stable Platform, which keeps the platform, on which the accelerometers are mounted, always level and aligned to North, and also measures acceleration relative to the platform. Alignment and levelling is done only once for each flight with the aircraft stationary on the ground. Once aligned, the inertial system is not and cannot be re-aligned for the remainder of the flight. Attitude data is still valid, and will continue to drive servo attitude and heading instruments or EFIS indications.

learning.explanation: AIR DATA COMPUTER (ADC) An Air Data Computer (ADC) is used by aircrafts to acquire data from pitot and static pressure sensors, data buses and analog inputs and convert those raw inputs into electrical signals, obtaining key air data parameters such as altitude, airspeed, height deviation and temperature to ensure safe and accurate flight detail, on both rotary and fixed wing aircraft. The ADC collects relevant air data, automatically eliminates the position errors of its individual sensors, computes the required output parameters and provides them to as many systems as desired. Some air data can be displayed without further computations. These are the TAT, altitude and IAS. Because systems errors are internally corrected, IAS is equal to CAS. The centralised processing of air data parameters allows for the computation of additional outputs, which could not be obtained from separate instruments. learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. The accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Gyro-stabilised platforms are generally costly, heavy, and require a lengthy alignment procedure. With the introduction of relatively low cost, high-performance digital computers, these systems have been steadily replaced by mathematical computer software models, which modify the output signals from accelerometers that are strapped directly to the airframe. Referred to as an inertial reference system (IRS), it works on the same fundamental principles as the INS. The strap-down system dispenses with the gimbal mounted stable element and instead uses solid-state ring laser gyros (RLG). These gyros are not required to stabilise the accelerometers, as in the case of an INS, but provide aeroplane orientation, by determining the rate of rotation around each of the aeroplane axes.

key_points: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration
This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night
The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information
learning.explanation: An Inertial Navigation System (INS) provides the aeroplane’s velocity and position by continuously measuring and integrating its acceleration. This system relies on no external references, is unaffected by weather, and can operate during the day or night. The products of an INS are position (latitude/longitude), speed (kt), distance (nautical miles), and other navigational information. The quality of information is dependent on the accuracy of the initial (input) data, and the precision with which the system aligns to True North. For navigation in a horizontal plane, two accelerometers are needed, which are normally aligned with True North and True East. To keep the reference valid, the accelerometers are mounted on a gyro-stabilised platform, which maintains the correct orientation during all aeroplane manoeuvres. Rate integrating gyros are for use as sensors to detect any departure of the platform from its level and desired alignment. BOUNDED ERRORS These errors build up to a maximum positive and negative values, and return to zero within each 84.4 minutes Schuler cycle and thus averages out over the period. The main causes of these errors are: - platform tilt, due to initial misalignment - inaccurate measurement of acceleration by accelerometers - integrator errors in the first integration stage UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE TRACK ERRORS These errors arise from the misalignment of the accelerometers in the horizontal plane, and the main causes of these errors are: - Initial azimuth misalignment of the platform. - Wander of the azimuth gyro. UNBOUNDED ERRORS - CUMULATIVE DISTANCE ERROR These errors give rise to cumulative errors in the recording of the total distance travelled. The main causes of this error are: - Wander in the levelling gyros. - Integrator errors in the second stage of integration. INHERENT ERRORS The irregular shape and composition of the Earth, together with the movement of the Earth through space, and other factors provide further possible sources of error. Such errors vary from system to system, depending upon the balance achieved between accuracy on one hand and the simplicity of design, reliability, ease of construction and cost of production on the other.

learning.explanation: The Inertial Reference System (IRS) receives data from three internal Ring Laser gyros (RLGs), and three internal accelerometers, measuring accelerations on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). Other data is also required, such as the: TAS - to calculate the wind speed/direction. Initial position – because actual aircraft position at any point during the flight, is calculated from the distance and direction flown from the initial reference position entered in the system. Barometric altitude – to stabilize the vertical navigation, thus stabilizing vertical velocity and inertial altitude information. The platform can output the inertial height by itself, but its accuracy is insufficient for precise height control, hence the barometric altitude input. The initial alignment and leveling of the IRS need to be carried out when the aircraft is stationary and on the ground. A set of three accelerometers will sense gravitational acceleration that will derive the local vertical of the platform. Once the vertical is found thanks to the gravity, any change of attitude in space will be detected, but they will only come from the Earth’s rotation (on the ground when stationary). Moreover, by detecting the drift due to the earth’s rotation, the Inertial Reference Unit (IRU) will be able to internally calculate the True North. Latitude can also be internally calculated, but because this calculation is not sufficiently precise, a manual position input is required from the flight crew for this alignment sequence. Therefore, the system will compare the inserted latitude with the calculated one and compute precisely the aircraft’s position. On the other hand, the IRS cannot calculate/measure longitude, therefore the only reference is the one provided by the pilot during the alignment process.

learning.explanation: Note: Obviously the wording is not very specific in this question, and we could use any further feedback for clarification on what EASA are asking. If you do have any further exam feedback, please let us know in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Inertial Navigation Systems are devices which allow us to have a self contained method of navigating, via just the accelerations of the aircraft. The basic principle is that, if an INS knows the initial location of the aircraft, and knows that it is completely still at that time (during initialisation), then it can precisely measure the aircraft's turns and accelerations to calculate its current position. It uses the mathematical process of integration to first work out the aircraft's velocity and direction, then integrates again to find the change in distance, which it then adds/removes from the original location. The oldest INSs use a "stable platform" design, which is a large platform that is kept pointing towards True North and perfectly upright, no matter the aircraft's heading or attitude. It manages this by using 3 rate-integrating gyros to measure the aircraft's turns around all three axes, and counter them by moving the platform the other way. It can then use 2 accelerometers to calculate the North-South acceleration, and the East-West accelerations, which are fed into a mechanical computer (a complex set of cogs and gears) that provide an output of speed and position, and other useful metrics. More modern aircraft use Inertial Reference Systems (IRSs), which are a form of INS, but are connected directly to the aircraft (no stable platform). These are much lighter, and less complex to have on board, as they use a set of 3 ring laser gyroscopes and 3 accelerometers to measure all the rotations and accelerations, and then calculates into their various components (North-South, East-West and Vertical) using modern computer methods. This is called a strapdown system, as it is fixed to the aircraft, and is much more usable with other systems, as it can feed info to the FMS, etc. This question is not very well worded, as the question is asking about inertial navigation systems, but the most correct answer (and the answer from feedback) is actually more related to IRSs. To clarify, we can go through each option: "true airspeed (TAS) on the x, y and z axes." This is quite blatantly wrong, airspeed is measured in one axis by the pitot tubes. "indicated Airspeed (IAS) on the x, y and z axes." Same as above, still wrong. "acceleration along the aircraft's pitch, roll and yaw axes." This one is nearly correct, as it does sense accelerations, but not necessarily along these axes (and these axes refer to rotations). INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions (and maybe vertically). "acceleration along the north-south, east-west and vertical axes." This is most correct, but only just. As mentioned above, INSs sense accelerations in the North-South and East-West directions. They can sense vertical accelerations also, if they have a third accelerometer, but this is not so well documented in the learning objectives, and is more to do with IRSs, which all measure vertical acceleration as part of their normal process. This is why this question can garner some opposing views, depending on interpretation. So far, this is our best option.

content.question: Consider an aircraft being flown manually with LOC mode (tracking of the localizer beam) engaged and with flight directors ON. If the aircraft is to the left of the localizer beam, what will the vertical command bar show?

The commands from the Flight Director computer are also modelled so that any command given will not unduly over stress the airframe

content.question: When engaged, the autopilot manoeuvres the aeroplane in accordance within a set of control laws. The purpose of these control laws is to…

options.A: ensure any movement of the control surface(s) is smooth and accurate for improved passenger comfort.
options.B: prevent the ability to by-pass the computers or the standby systems to operate without the computers.
options.C: prevent unacceptable loads on the aeroplane or prevent hazardous deviations from the flight path.
options.D: prevent the aeroplane from deviating from its desired flight path by an amount exceeding the limits established by the operator.

key_points: AUTO PILOT CONTROL LAWS The autopilot must be able to manoeuvre the aircraft logically and safely in a similar manner to the way a human pilot should
This means ensuring the autopilot does not break aircraft limitations in terms of speed, load factor, pitch and bank limits etc
The autopilot should be able to use a satisfactory amount of the performance of the aircraft otherwise the manoeuvres would take too long to execute
learning.explanation: AUTO PILOT CONTROL LAWS The autopilot must be able to manoeuvre the aircraft logically and safely in a similar manner to the way a human pilot should. This means ensuring the autopilot does not break aircraft limitations in terms of speed, load factor, pitch and bank limits etc. The autopilot should be able to use a satisfactory amount of the performance of the aircraft otherwise the manoeuvres would take too long to execute. Whenever the autopilot is required to make a correction either for stability or when referring to a particular flight path, the control response will always be in proportion to deviation or corrective action required but only up to a limit that prevents the autopilot attempting a manoeuvre that would cause an excursion from the safe flight envelope. Command Speed Limiting The AFS provides speed, pitch and thrust commands to avoid exceeding the following limit speeds: - VMO/MMO. - Wing flap limiting speeds. - Landing gear speeds. - Minimum speed. Reversion Modes During some flight situations, speed control by the AFDS or A/T alone could be insufficient to prevent exceeding a limit speed. If this occurs, AFDS and A/T mode automatically revert to a more effective combination. The reversion modes are: - Placard Limit reversion. - Minimum airspeed reversion. Mode reversion occurs slightly before reaching the limit speed. Flight Envelope Protection Flight envelope protection is installed with the aim of ensuring that the aircraft remains within the normal flight envelope in all phases of flight The system provides protection in all phases of flight to prevent the aircraft exceeding the limits for the following parameters: - Angle of Attack - Speed - Pitch attitude - Bank angle - Loadfactor

content.question: The crew of a multi-pilot aircraft are performing an approach, with the autopilot (AP) coupled to the ILS. They notice the AP system making large corrections in pitch close to the ground, leading to oscillations. The safest course of action for the crew is to…

options.B: Disconnect the AP and perform a go-around.
options.C: Conduct a go-around with the AP engaged.
options.D: Reduce thrust with the AP engaged.

key_points: The safest course of action for the crew when they notice the autopilot (AP) making large pitch corrections close to the ground, leading to oscillations is to disconnect the AP and perform a go-around
Timely manual intervention is crucial as a way of mitigating loss of control

As it is unclear how close the aircraft is to the ground or the severity of deviation, disconnecting the AP and continuing to fly manually in this situation can be hazardous and may result in an unstable approach or even loss of control
learning.explanation: The safest course of action for the crew when they notice the autopilot (AP) making large pitch corrections close to the ground, leading to oscillations is to disconnect the AP and perform a go-around. Timely manual intervention is crucial as a way of mitigating loss of control. As it is unclear how close the aircraft is to the ground or the severity of deviation, disconnecting the AP and continuing to fly manually in this situation can be hazardous and may result in an unstable approach or even loss of control. Reducing thrust with the AP engaged is unlikely to resolve the issue and may even worsen the situation. Conducting a go-around with the AP engaged can be risky as well, as the system may continue to make large pitch corrections and exacerbate the oscillations. Furthermore, a automatic go-around is only possible when the aircraft is set for a dual channel approach (both AP engaged).

content.question:
The automatic synchronisation function of an autopilot control system:
1 – operates only when the autopilot is engaged
2 – prevents the aircraft's control system from jerking when disengaging the autopilot
3 – prevents the aircraft's control system from jerking when engaging the autopilot
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The automatic pitch trim is used to: ensure the airplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is disengaged
permits the elevator to always be in neutral position with respect to the horizontal stabilizer
In other words, it off-loads any steady-state elevator deflection
learning.explanation: The automatic pitch trim is used to: ensure the airplane is properly trimmed when the autopilot is disengaged. permits the elevator to always be in neutral position with respect to the horizontal stabilizer. In other words, it off-loads any steady-state elevator deflection. When the autopilot is engaged, the role of the automatic pitch trim is to relieve the autopilot servo motor and return the aircraft in-trim when disconnecting the autopilot. It basically provides a smooth ‘HAND-OVER’ when disengaging the autopilot. Caution! Do not confuse the auto trim with the automatic synchronization function which is providing a smooth `TAKE-OVER` when engaging the autopilot. The auto synchronization function will prevent the autopilot engagement it is inoperative, as this might result in an abrupt snatch and jerks of the autopilot during engagement. For an airplane fitted with a mechanical flight control system, the automatic pitch trim system is active whenever the autopilot is engaged. On the other hand, when flying a fly-by-wire aircraft, the automatic pitch trim is always active either you are flying it manually or with the autopilot engaged. When flying an FBW aircraft manually, the system eliminates the need for the pilot to make control column inputs (or manual trim) to compensate for flight path parameter alterations such as thrust changes, landing gear configuration changes, or slats/flaps configuration changes. Summary: `HAND-OVER` - automatic pitch trim function. `TAKE-OVER` - automatic synchronization function.

content.question: While performing an ILS approach, what could be the danger of activating the approach mode (APP) if you are high above the glide path?

options.B: The autopilot could initiate a premature descent and fly into terrain.

key_points: The ILS has two main components: the localizer and the glide slope
The localizer provides lateral guidance for the aircraft, ensuring that it remains aligned with the centerline of the runway
The glide slope provides vertical guidance, indicating the angle at which the aircraft should descend towards the runway
learning.explanation: The ILS has two main components: the localizer and the glide slope. The localizer provides lateral guidance for the aircraft, ensuring that it remains aligned with the centerline of the runway. The glide slope provides vertical guidance, indicating the angle at which the aircraft should descend towards the runway. One of the challenges of the ILS is that it can produce false signals, known as false lobes. False lobes are due to both the weak sidelobes of the original lobes and the reflection of the lower signals off the ground, creating additional, spurious signals that can confuse the aircraft's receiver. False lobes can cause the aircraft to deviate from the correct glide slope or localizer path, potentially leading to an unsafe condition.

options.C: attitude commands for use by the Stability Augmentation System (SAS).

key_points: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude
Flight director information supplied by a FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI)
The vertical command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the bank angle of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. Flight director information supplied by a FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI). The vertical command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the bank angle of the aircraft. The vertical bar is always associated with the roll channel. The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft. The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel.

content.question: Assuming the autopilot is in heading hold mode, what would happen to the autopilot if the flux valve started drifting in an aircraft equipped with a single flux valve?

options.A: The autopilot would start drifting off too.
options.B: The autopilot would disengage automatically.
options.C: The 'FLUX ERROR' warning light would illuminate on the autopilot control panel, and the autopilot would use its internal logic to compensate for the error.
options.D: Nothing. The autopilot is independent from the flux valve.

key_points: A flux valve consists of two identical bars or spokes of highly permeable (easily magnetised and de-magnetised) material, mounted on a common hub

The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft (which also positions the compass card indicator – the indication of heading to the pilot)
Autopilot Heading Mode The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select, this is called Heading Mode
learning.explanation: A flux valve consists of two identical bars or spokes of highly permeable (easily magnetised and de-magnetised) material, mounted on a common hub. The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft (which also positions the compass card indicator – the indication of heading to the pilot). Autopilot Heading Mode The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select, this is called Heading Mode. In this mode the pilot selects a desired heading, either using a knob on the HSI, using the central FDS/autopilot panel or on the MCP. The Flight Director roll bar commands the aeroplane to fly to the Pre- Selected Heading, and subsequently to hold that heading. To achieve this, the computer receives inputs from the attitude reference source, the VG, and the course from the compass system. If the heading source is purely magnetic, the Autopilot will follow the heading regarding this source. If is is incorrect, the autopilot will follow an incorrect heading. Having two flux-valves with combined outputs, is used to reduce errors which otherwise may be present in systems using single pendulously mounted magnetic field responsive devices.

content.question: What commands does the flight director issue during take-off mode?

options.A: The pitch mode holds attitude to avoid obstacles and maintain adequate clearance, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the LOC.
options.B: The pitch mode holds a constant pitch attitude, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the LOC.
options.C: The pitch mode holds a constant pitch attitude to ensure obstacle clearance, and the roll mode maintains the runway direction through the SID.
options.D: The pitch mode commands an attitude to maintain a defined speed above V2 and tracks the runway heading.

key_points: The Flight Director takeoff mode is engaged by pressing either of the TO/GA switches on the throttles
The AFDS annunciation will be TO/GA
During take-off, prior to 60 KIAS, the initial FD commands are for 10° nose-down pitch and wings level
learning.explanation: The Flight Director takeoff mode is engaged by pressing either of the TO/GA switches on the throttles. The AFDS annunciation will be TO/GA. During take-off, prior to 60 KIAS, the initial FD commands are for 10° nose-down pitch and wings level. At 60 kt IAS, the FD command changes to 15° nose-up and wings level. At lift-off, the pitch command continues at 15° nose-up until sufficient climb rate is acquired. Pitch then commands MCP speed (normally V2) plus 20 knots. This speed is calculated and set during the pre-flight checks. The roll command maintains HDG SEL - the roll mode keeps the aircraft aligned with the runway heading. Next, when either autopilot is engaged or when the MCP speed selector is rotated, 20 kt IAS is added automatically to the MCP IAS display.

content.question:
The flight guidance system has different modes. Considering the autopilot/flight director, which of the following describes one feature of the go-around mode?
When selected, the go-around mode engages and the aeroplane climbs...

options.A: only if the aeroplane is below the selected missed approach altitude and following an ILS.
options.B: when it is approaching the missed approach point or minimum descent altitude for the approach.
options.C: whether it is below or above the selected missed approach altitude at the point of initiation.
options.D: only if the selected missed approach altitude is above the aeroplane at the point of initiation.

learning.explanation: 022.06.02.01.08: Explain the following mixed modes: take-off and go-around (TOGA); approach (APP). The Go-around mode is one of the three mixed modes mentioned in the EASA LOs above, with the other two being take-off and approach modes. All three of these modes interact with the autothrottle and autopilot systems to achieve the desired outcomes. When the A/T ARM switch is turned on, the A/T go-around mode becomes active below 2000 feet RA, whether or not the AFDS is engaged. Once activated, the A/T go-around mode remains available for engagement until 2 seconds after touchdown. To engage this mode, you simply press the TOGA switch. When engaged, "GA" is displayed for the A/T, and the thrust levers move to the reduced go-around thrust setting, resulting in a climb rate of 1000 to 2000 feet per minute. Pressing the TOGA switch a second time causes the A/T to advance the thrust to the full go-around N1 limit. On Boeing aircraft, this entails pressing TOGA, while on Airbus planes, it involves moving the throttles into the TOGA detent. In either case, the engines power up to full thrust, and the autopilot disengages the approach mode, allowing the aircraft to climb away from the ground. It's important to note that the Go-around mode is not constrained by specific altitudes or heights. Therefore, if the pilot initiates a go-around, the aircraft will climb regardless of whether it is below or above the pre-selected missed approach altitude.

content.question: During an automatic landing, between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot maintains…

options.A: a vertical speed depending on the GPS height.
options.B: a constant flight path angle with reference to the ground.
options.C: a constant vertical speed.
options.D: a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height.

key_points: For an A320 or B737, a standard VS at a standard glide path angle and aircraft weight is between 700 and 800 ft/min
As you can imagine if the aircraft keeps this rate of descent until touch down, it will do nothing but making a hole into the runway
Therefore, the autopilot system needs some inputs to flare the aircraft and achieve a smooth touch down
learning.explanation: For an A320 or B737, a standard VS at a standard glide path angle and aircraft weight is between 700 and 800 ft/min. As you can imagine if the aircraft keeps this rate of descent until touch down, it will do nothing but making a hole into the runway. Therefore, the autopilot system needs some inputs to flare the aircraft and achieve a smooth touch down. These inputs are the radio height, the wind speed/direction, etc. At 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. The higher the VS the sooner the aircraft will start to flare.

Refer to figure.
During an autoland, what triggers the FLARE mode?

options.A: The glide slope mode.
options.B: The radio altitude, when it reaches about 50 ft.
options.C: The barometric altitude, when it reaches about 50 ft.
options.D: The localizer mode.

key_points: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III
An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions

Fail-passive automatic landing system An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: Category IIIA (CAT IIIA) operation means a precision instrument approach and landing operation using ILS or MLS with: - DH lower than 100 ft; - RVR not less than 200 m; Note: Automatic landing is not directly connected to CAT III. An automatic landing system is only an equipment providing automatic control of the aircraft during the approach and landing and is not related to particular weather conditions. Fail-passive automatic landing system An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail passive means in case of a failure of any part of the system the autoland system will turn itself off and the crew has to take over. An example of an autoland sequence: - Approach (APP) mode armed - Localizer and Glide Slope Armed - Localizer Capture - Glide Slope Capture - 400 - 330 feet RA: If FLARE is armed by approximately 350 ft RA, both A/Ps automatically disengage. - At 45 feet Gear Altitude (GA)/50 ft RA: The FLARE mode is automatically engaged - Roll-out In case visual references at the moment of an abnormal occurrence (such as 'NO FLARE' indication) are sufficient and flying conditions such that a visual manual landing can be safely performed, continuation of the approach remains always an option and a crew decision.

content.question: Which of the following is correct regarding the initial phase of the autopilot?

options.A: A given rate of change of trajectory is maintained to achieve a new parameter without undershooting.
options.B: A new trajectory is obtained via a change in attitude to achieve a desired parameter.
options.C: The autopilot obtains a trajectory through the third channel in case of failure.
options.D: The autopilot maintains the set parameter without any change.

key_points: When a mode is engaged, the following sequence of events applies: Initial phase In this phase, the attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter
The trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter
Capture phase The aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting
learning.explanation: When a mode is engaged, the following sequence of events applies: Initial phase In this phase, the attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter. The trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter. Capture phase The aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting. Tracking or hold phase The aircraft will maintain the set parameter until a new change has been initiated.

content.question: Which statement is correct regarding the V/S and FPA autopilot modes?

options.A: V/S is an altitude gain/loss in relation to time while FPA is an altitude gain/loss in relation to ground distance.
options.B: Both V/S and FPA maintain a vertical speed as it is the main parameter during climb and descent.
options.C: V/S is an altitude gain/loss in relation to ground distance while FPA is an altitude gain/loss in relation to time.
options.D: FPA is to be used during non-precision approaches only, whereas V/S can be used during any other approach.

key_points: The V/S - FPA mode is a selected mode
It acquires and holds the vertical speed or the flight path angle displayed in the V/S - FPA window of the FCU
VERTICAL SPEED An aircraft's vertical speed is the positive or negative rate of altitude change with respect to time
learning.explanation: The V/S - FPA mode is a selected mode. It acquires and holds the vertical speed or the flight path angle displayed in the V/S - FPA window of the FCU. VERTICAL SPEED An aircraft's vertical speed is the positive or negative rate of altitude change with respect to time. This is usually expressed in feet per minute (ft/min). The Vertical Speed in an aircraft is indicated with a vertical speed indicator (VSI) or instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI). FLIGHT PATH ANGLE The Flight Path Angle is the angle between the Aircraft’s Velocity Vector and the Horizon. If you are flying in a level flight your Flight Path Angle will be zero (over the horizon), regardless of the Pitch Angle. During a descent, the Flight Path Angle will be negative (below the horizon) thus when climbing the Flight Path Angle will be positive (over the horizon). FLIGHT PATH VECTOR The circular symbol represents the aircraft's axis in relation to the vertical and lateral movement referenced to the Earth's surface. If you were stationary on the ground, the circle would be on the horizon line and centred in the display. The data received by the FPV is derived mostly from the Internal Reference System (IRS) of the aircraft; therefore, the Flight Path Vector provides an almost instantaneous display of flight path angle and drift information.

content.question: The basic modes of an autopilot consist of…

options.A: controlling the path of the aircraft vertically only.
options.B: controlling the path of the aircraft horizontally or vertically.
options.C: stabilising the aircraft around its centre of gravity.

The basic stability functions of the autopilot are provided by the inner loops
Guidance functions – Controlling the movements of the center of gravity in three-dimensional space
learning.explanation: Basic modes – Stabilizing the aircraft around its center of gravity. The basic stability functions of the autopilot are provided by the inner loops. Guidance functions – Controlling the movements of the center of gravity in three-dimensional space. These are the different functions of the autopilot that control the path of the aircraft. The guidance functions are provided by the outer loops. Guidance functions: ROLL modes PITCH modes Combined ROLL and PITCH Heading Select and Hold Altitude Select and Hold Approach Track Hold IAS/Mach Hold Go-around VOR/LOC Capture and Track Level Change Lateral Navigation LNAV Altitude Capture Vertical Speed Glideslope Capture and Track Basic (stabilization) functions: Pitch and bank angle hold (= attitude hold) Vertical Speed hold Wings level hold

content.question:
During a final approach, the flight director system is engaged in the G/S mode (tracking of ILS Glide Slope). The position of the horizontal command bar indicates:
1 – the position of the aircraft relative to the ILS Glide Slope
2 – the correction to be applied to the pitch angle in order to capture and follow the ILS Glide Slope
3 – the pitch angle of the aircraft
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft
The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel
When tracking the ILS glideslope, the horizontal command bar will indicate at which angle you should pitch the aircraft in order to get back on the glideslope
learning.explanation: The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft. The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel. When tracking the ILS glideslope, the horizontal command bar will indicate at which angle you should pitch the aircraft in order to get back on the glideslope. In other words, it will indicate the correction to be applied to the pitch angle in order to capture and then readapt this pitch angle so that you follow the ILS glideslope.

content.question: The pilot sets the autobrake to MAX due to fear of exceeding runway distance. The pilot will…

options.A: Not use reverse thrust.
options.B: Expect the autobrake system to apply necessary braking to stay on the runway.
options.C: Expect the autobrake system to apply maximum braking effort.
options.D: Expect the autobrake system to modulate braking pressure to maintain given rate.

key_points: Learning Objectives 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 021.04.03.04.04: Describe how an autobrake system setting will either apply maximum braking (RTO or MAX) or result in a given rate of deceleration, where the amount of braking applied may be affected by: the use of reverse thrust; slippery runway. While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above. Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. Note: On a Boeing 737, the 1, 2, 3, and MAX deceleration positions control the autobrake system during landing, modulating brake pressure to achieve specified deceleration rates until the aircraft comes to a complete stop. Regarding other options, the use of reverse thrust and autobrake is not mutually exclusive - Flight crews can employ reverse thrust in conjunction with autobrake for maximum deceleration. Although the autobrake system is designed to facilitate a smooth landing rollout and keep the aircraft on the runway, pilots must always conduct calculations to ensure that the aircraft does not exceed the available landing distance.

On a large aeroplane, the computer of the autopilot system uses, among others, input signals from the:
1 – ADC

The main components of an AP are the: Actuators, Autopilot MCP (mode control panel), FMA (flight mode annunciator (Airbus), mode annunciator panel (Boeing)), Computer, which uses inputs from the ADC (CAS, altitude), the MCP, and the attitude reference system (heading, attitude, vertical speed), the ILS receiver, etc
learning.explanation: In an autopilot system, the inner loops provide the stability functions, and the outer loops provide the guidance functions. The main components of an AP are the: Actuators, Autopilot MCP (mode control panel), FMA (flight mode annunciator (Airbus), mode annunciator panel (Boeing)), Computer, which uses inputs from the ADC (CAS, altitude), the MCP, and the attitude reference system (heading, attitude, vertical speed), the ILS receiver, etc.

content.question: In an autopilot system, What does the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) indicate?

options.A: Flight Warning System (FWS) modes.
options.B: AFCS and autothrust modes.
options.C: Weather radar modes.
options.D: EGPWS modes.

key_points: The Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is usually located on the top of the PFD and displays the active and the armed modes of the autopilot and auto-thrust (or auto-throttle) system
The flight crew uses this system to check and confirm any selection made on the autopilot control panel
From left to right, the FMA indicates the: Auto-thrust mode and autobrake modes (on more complex aircraft such as the A350)
learning.explanation: The Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is usually located on the top of the PFD and displays the active and the armed modes of the autopilot and auto-thrust (or auto-throttle) system. The flight crew uses this system to check and confirm any selection made on the autopilot control panel. From left to right, the FMA indicates the: Auto-thrust mode and autobrake modes (on more complex aircraft such as the A350). Autopilot/FD vertical modes. Autopilot/FD lateral modes. Approach capabilities (=autoland capabilities) and autopilot designator (1, 2, 1+2) and auto-thrust engagement status.

content.question: What happens if, during an automatic approach and landing, the radio altimeter fails?

options.A: The automatic landing system will NOT be able to perform the flare phase.
options.B: The automatic landing system will be fully operational.
options.C: The automatic braking sequence will be impacted.
options.D: The Glide Slope mode will NOT be operational.

key_points: When performing an automatic landing, a radio altimeter is required because the decision heights below CAT I limits (200 ft) are based on radio height and because the autopilot moves from one mode to another, for example, from FLARE to ROLLOUT, using a variety of inputs, particularly radio height
Should the radio altimeter fail during the autoland procedure, the height indication is removed and replaced by a warning flag
As the individual steps of the automatic landing procedure are triggered by radio heights, this situation requires the aircraft to go around and be landed manually
learning.explanation: When performing an automatic landing, a radio altimeter is required because the decision heights below CAT I limits (200 ft) are based on radio height and because the autopilot moves from one mode to another, for example, from FLARE to ROLLOUT, using a variety of inputs, particularly radio height. Should the radio altimeter fail during the autoland procedure, the height indication is removed and replaced by a warning flag. As the individual steps of the automatic landing procedure are triggered by radio heights, this situation requires the aircraft to go around and be landed manually. As for the incorrect options: Glideslope relies upon the ILS and not the radio altimeter. The autobrake relies on weight-on-wheels, throttles retarded and wheels spun up to speed. The autoland will not be fully operational.

content.question: An autoland system (autopilot) is described as fail operational when it is…

options.A: Fail operational hybrid system.
options.B: Fail redundant.
options.C: Fail passive.
options.D: Fail safe.

key_points: EASA AIR OPS CS-AWO 300 Applicability and Terminology Fail-passive Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically

Fail-operational Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system

A fail-safe is a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause minimal or no harm to other equipment, to the environment or to people
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS CS-AWO 300 Applicability and Terminology Fail-passive Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail-operational Automatic Landing System: An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure, the approach, flare and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system. A fail-safe is a design feature or practice that in the event of a specific type of failure, inherently responds in a way that will cause minimal or no harm to other equipment, to the environment or to people. Therefore, we can say that fail-operational is fail-safe.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the system which ensures synchronisation in an autopilot slaved powered control circuit?

options.A: Such system can itself, when it fails, prevent the automatic pilot from being engaged.
options.B: Synchronisation is inhibited when the automatic pilot is engaged.
options.C: This system prevents uncommanded surface deflection when the automatic pilot is disengaged.
options.D: It intervenes only when the automatic pilot has been engaged.

key_points: AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION Before the autopilot is engaged, it must be ensured that the take-over is effected smoothly and without "snatching" of the aircraft's control system
This is achieved by synchronization of aircraft control systems
Autopilot systems synchronization is effected by designed synchronizing circuits
learning.explanation: AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION Before the autopilot is engaged, it must be ensured that the take-over is effected smoothly and without "snatching" of the aircraft's control system. This is achieved by synchronization of aircraft control systems. Autopilot systems synchronization is effected by designed synchronizing circuits. These synchronizing circuits will automatically sense any existing "standing signals" in the pitch and roll channels and automatically send this data to a synchronizer unit. The synchronizer unit will create equal and opposite attitude signal. Without the synchronizing circuits, the autopilot engagement could cause unwanted and/or violent aircraft manoeuvres. Therefore, it is important to note that, in the event of a synchronizing circuits failure, the autopilot may be prevented from engaging.

content.question: The purpose of a flight director is to…

options.A: convey air traffic control information to the pilot.
options.B: provide an automatic landing system function.
options.C: automatically steer the aircraft to waypoints selected on the CDU.
options.D: reduce the pilots workload by presenting data in the form of control commands.

key_points: ‘convey air traffic control information to the pilot’ – the FD system is not linked in any way with the information provided by the ATC
‘provide an automatic landing system function’ – the FD is most of the time ON during Autoland, however, it is not the main system allowing the automatic landing
The systems crucial to the Autoland are the autopilot, the radio, altimeter, and the auto-throttle system
learning.explanation: ‘convey air traffic control information to the pilot’ – the FD system is not linked in any way with the information provided by the ATC. ‘provide an automatic landing system function’ – the FD is most of the time ON during Autoland, however, it is not the main system allowing the automatic landing. The systems crucial to the Autoland are the autopilot, the radio, altimeter, and the auto-throttle system. ‘automatically steer the aircraft to waypoints selected on the CDU’ – it is the autopilot’s function to automatically follow the flight plan inserted in the FMS via the CDU. The autopilot can operate without the FDs ON, so this answer option is also incorrect. ‘reduce the pilots' workload by presenting data in the form of control commands’ – the flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. When flying manually, the FD bars indicate the optimum path according to the selected modes, and this ultimately reduces their workload.

content.question: The crew is flying a heading assigned by ATC, 20 NM to the left and parallel to the planned route, for weather avoidance. You select the lateral navigation mode and the Pilot Monitoring (PM) reads the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA), the navigation mode is armed. options.C: It will turn right towards the next waypoint.
options.D: It will enter an ICAO standard holding pattern.

key_points: With the Navigation Mode ARMED, it will automatically engage if the aircraft heading/track line intercepts the active flight plan before the TO waypoint and the aircraft reaches the active flight plan leg

In this case, the pilot would have to ask for a heading to the right to intercept the active flight plane or insert a DIRECT TO the next waypoint, otherwise the aircraft would maintain present heading
