For example, on the B737 the mode remains available up to 2 seconds after touch down. Note: Go-Around basically tells the autopilot to pitch up with wings level and the autothrust to select a high thrust setting for climb out. The pilot must retract the gear and flaps as practical.

content.question: What is the basic principle of a closed loop system?

options.A: Measurement of the controlled variable, calculation of the control error, and adjustment of the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error.
options.B: Adjustment of the controlled variable based on a fixed setting.
options.C: Calculation of the control error, adjustment of the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error, and without feedback.
options.D: Measurement of an independent variable, calculation of the control error, and adjustment of the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error.

key_points: The basic principle of a closed-loop system is to measure a controlled variable, calculate the control error, and adjust the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error
Let’s see an example
If an aircraft flying with the autopilot ON is cruising and suddenly a gust makes it to climb, the rate gyros of the IRS will detect this displacement
learning.explanation: The basic principle of a closed-loop system is to measure a controlled variable, calculate the control error, and adjust the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error. Let’s see an example. If an aircraft flying with the autopilot ON is cruising and suddenly a gust makes it to climb, the rate gyros of the IRS will detect this displacement. The gyros will then send a signal to a detector (=signal processor) that is proportional to the rate of change of attitude. The detector that has received this signal will compute a corrective signal and will send it to the elevator servo motors. After the elevator has been moved, feedback of the elevator position is sent to the detector so that the actual position of the elevator and the required one is compared. If the elevator still hasn’t achieved its required position, the detector unit will compute another corrective signal proportional to the new displacement. This feedback operation will continue until the elevator hasn’t achieved the required position.

options.B: The Localizer center line is to the left.
options.C: You must turn right to capture the localizer.
options.D: You must roll to the right to have the FD bars centered.

key_points: In a Flight Director System (FDS), pitch and roll commands compute to achieve or maintain a particular condition of flight
The commands from the Flight Director computer are also modelled so that any command given will not unduly over stress the airframe
For example, in Heading Mode the Flight Directors will indicate a fly to command to bring the aircraft on to the desired heading
learning.explanation: In a Flight Director System (FDS), pitch and roll commands compute to achieve or maintain a particular condition of flight. The commands from the Flight Director computer are also modelled so that any command given will not unduly over stress the airframe. For example, in Heading Mode the Flight Directors will indicate a fly to command to bring the aircraft on to the desired heading. Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command. When centred, the command bar indicates the achievement of the required pitch attitude. By virtue of the fact that the command bar deflections are the resultant of a combination of system inputs, do not regard them as positional to acquire a required state. They are simply a command for change in pitch and/or roll attitude, e.g. - Pitch Command Bar UP - Pitch Up - Roll Command Bar RIGHT - Roll Right Pitch Command Bar UP - Pitch Up

content.question:
You are the pilot flying of an aeroplane established on an ILS to perform an Autoland. Your aircraft is equipped with two autopilots, which are both engaged, and the Autoland capability of the aeroplane is fail operational. Passing 2000 ft ONE IRS fails, with the only technical consequence being a downgraded landing capability. Given the information below, what are the consequences of this failure and what should you do?
Approach minima: 0 ft
Alert height: 100 ft

options.A: There is NO annunciation of the failure because the operation of the autopilots is NOT affected, but the landing capability is now limited fail-operational. The pilots should continue the approach to Autoland.
options.B: The landing capability is now fail-passive and the approach may be continued to revised minima if all the required actions can be completed in a timely manner.
options.C: There is an annunciation of the failure, and the landing capability is now fail-passive. The pilots must prepare to perform a manual landing.
options.D: Since the function of the autopilots is NOT affected by the failure of the IRS, the pilots can continue the approach to complete the Autoland with fail-operation status.

key_points: ALERT HEIGHT The alert height is evaluated and defined during the aircraft certification
It refers only to autoland operations with fail-operational landing system

The alert height defines the point during an approach with the lowest minima (CAT IIIB): - Before which (above AH) a go-around (or full manual take-over) should be decided and initiated if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system (the probability of a second failure remains high and must be considered); - After which (below AH), if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system, the approach and autoland can be continued (the probability of a second failure is negligible)
learning.explanation: ALERT HEIGHT The alert height is evaluated and defined during the aircraft certification. It refers only to autoland operations with fail-operational landing system. The alert height defines the point during an approach with the lowest minima (CAT IIIB): - Before which (above AH) a go-around (or full manual take-over) should be decided and initiated if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system (the probability of a second failure remains high and must be considered); - After which (below AH), if a single failure affects the fail-operational landing system, the approach and autoland can be continued (the probability of a second failure is negligible). FAIL-OPERATIONAL AUTOMATIC LANDING SYSTEM An automatic landing system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure below alert height, the remaining part of the automatic system allows the aircraft to complete the approach, flare, and landing. In the event of a failure, the automatic landing system operates as a fail-passive system. FAIL-PASSIVE AUTOMATIC LANDING SYSTEM An automatic landing system is fail-passive if, in the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail passive means in case of a failure of any part of the system, the autoland system will turn itself off and the crew has to take over. An example of an autoland sequence: - Approach (APP) mode armed - Localizer and Glide Slope Armed - Localizer Capture - Glide Slope Capture - 400 - 330 feet RA: If FLARE is armed by approximately 350 ft RA, both A/Ps automatically disengage. - At 45 feet Gear Altitude (GA)/ 50 ft RA: The FLARE mode is automatically engaged - Roll-out FAILURES AND ASSOCIATED ACTIONS As a general rule, if a failure occurs above 1000 ft AGL, the approach may be continued if all required actions are completed, the updated approach briefing is performed and the appropriate Decision heigh/altitude set. Below 1000 ft (and down to Alert Height), the occurrence of any failure requires a go around and a reassessment of the landing capability. It has been considered that below 1000 ft, not enough time is available for the crew to perform the necessary switching, to check system configuration and limitation and brief for minima.

key_points: The Flight Guidance (FG) part of the FMGS controls: ‐ The Flight Director (FD) ‐ The Autopilot (AP) ‐ The Autothrust (A/THR)
The AP and FD pitch modes can control a target SPD/MACH or a vertical trajectory, and the A/THR mode can control a fixed thrust or a target SPD/MACH
However, the AP/FD and the A/THR cannot both control a target SPD/MACH simultaneously
learning.explanation: The Flight Guidance (FG) part of the FMGS controls: ‐ The Flight Director (FD) ‐ The Autopilot (AP) ‐ The Autothrust (A/THR). The AP and FD pitch modes can control a target SPD/MACH or a vertical trajectory, and the A/THR mode can control a fixed thrust or a target SPD/MACH. However, the AP/FD and the A/THR cannot both control a target SPD/MACH simultaneously. Therefore the AP/FD pitch modes and A/THR mode are coordinated as follows: ‐ If an AP/FD pitch mode controls a vertical trajectory, the A/THR mode controls the target SPD/MACH. ‐ If an AP/FD pitch mode controls a target SPD or MACH, the A/THR mode controls the thrust. ‐ If no AP/FD pitch mode is engaged, the A/THR mode reverts to controlling the SPD/MACH mode. In other words, the selection of an AP/FD pitch mode determines which mode the A/THR controls. The FMGS has guidance parameters for both AP/FD lateral and vertical modes. The AP/FD lateral modes are the same. Two types of autopilot and flight director modes are available to guide the aircraft: ‐ One that steers the aircraft along the lateral, vertical, and speed profiles according to the data the pilot inserts into the MCDU. Flight Management (in the Flight Management and Guidance Computer) computes the corresponding guidance targets. ‐ The other that steers the aircraft according to target values that the pilot selects and the FCU windows display.

learning.explanation: Failure or malfunctions of any of the systems required to perform an automatic landing can result in a degradation of autoland performance. learning.explanation: The autopilot must be able to manouevre the aircraft logically and safely in a similar manner to the way a human pilot should. Whenever the autopilot is required to make a correction either for stability or when referring to a particular flight path, the control response will always be in proportion to deviation or corrective action required but only up to a limit that prevents the autopilot attempting a manouevre that would cause an excursion from the safe flight envelope. Control Laws, are used to determine exactly how the control demands are translated into control movements.

key_points: In the event of a malfunction in one autopilot of a fail-operational system during the approach, the system remains in a fail-passive mode, enabling the completion of the automatic landing procedure
An alert height has been established to guide the crew's response to a system downgrade

If the failure occurs above the alert height, it is generally required for pilots to discontinue the approach, initiate a go-around, stabilize the aircraft, assess the nature of the failure, and execute a new approach based on the remaining capabilities of the aircraft
learning.explanation: In the event of a malfunction in one autopilot of a fail-operational system during the approach, the system remains in a fail-passive mode, enabling the completion of the automatic landing procedure. An alert height has been established to guide the crew's response to a system downgrade. If the failure occurs above the alert height, it is generally required for pilots to discontinue the approach, initiate a go-around, stabilize the aircraft, assess the nature of the failure, and execute a new approach based on the remaining capabilities of the aircraft. However, when a failure occurs below the alert height, the approach should typically continue as planned with an automatic landing. The only circumstance that would trigger a go-around below the alert height is the activation of the "autoland warning light." This light indicates the system's absolute inability to complete the automatic landing and can be caused by factors such as dual autopilot failure, loss of ILS (Instrument Landing System) localizer and/or glide slope signals, excessive deviations from the ILS beams, or failure of a radio altimeter with significant deviations between radio altimeter readings from both sides. CS-AWO - All Weather Operations CS-AWO 300 Applicability and Terminology (6) The alert height is a specified radio height, based on the characteristics of the aeroplane and its fail-operational landing system. In operational use, if a failure occurred above the alert height in one of the required redundant operational systems in the aeroplane (including, where appropriate, ground roll guidance and the reversionary mode in a hybrid system), the approach would be discontinued and a go-around executed unless reversion to a higher decision height is possible. If a failure in one of the required redundant operational systems occurred below the alert height, it would be ignored and the approach continued.

The sequence of events when a mode is engaged and the different phases are as follows: - initial phase: where attitude is changed to obtain a new trajectory in order to achieve the new parameter; the trajectory will be based on rate of closure which is again based on the difference between the original parameter and the new parameter; - capture phase: where the aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting; - tracking or hold phase: where the aircraft will maintain the set parameter until a new change has been initiated.

key_points: In order to anticipate turns, climbs and descents for smooth flying the Flight Director System (FDS) can use the raw data, compute and signal commands to either the pilot via the flight director bars or directly to the autopilot

learning.explanation: In order to anticipate turns, climbs and descents for smooth flying the Flight Director System (FDS) can use the raw data, compute and signal commands to either the pilot via the flight director bars or directly to the autopilot. This is called computed information and is derived from the rate of change of deviation of the incoming signal. As the rate of change of deviation from the desired track increases, the FDS computes that in order to intercept the track correctly, rather than fly straight through, it must indicate a turn onto track. Movement of the roll command bar to the left or right requires rolling the aeroplane to the left or right, in order to centre the command bar, and to satisfy the computed command. When centred, the command bar indicates the achievement of the required roll attitude. The simplest nav mode is to have the aircraft keep flying in the direction you select. This is called Heading Mode. In this mode the pilot selects a desired heading, either using a knob on the HSI, using the central FDS/autopilot panel or on the MCP. The FDS will indicate a fly to command to bring the aircraft on to the desired heading.

key_points: Control Wheel Steering (CWS) A Control Wheel Steering mode (CWS) is provided in some automatic flight control systems
Its purpose being to enable the pilot to manoeuvre their aircraft in pitch and/or roll, through the automatic control system without disconnecting the autopilot
The signals for the A/P are produced by transducers in the control column
learning.explanation: Control Wheel Steering (CWS) A Control Wheel Steering mode (CWS) is provided in some automatic flight control systems. Its purpose being to enable the pilot to manoeuvre their aircraft in pitch and/or roll, through the automatic control system without disconnecting the autopilot. The signals for the A/P are produced by transducers in the control column. Pressing a CWS engage switch, engages the A/P pitch and roll axes in the CWS mode and displays CWS P and CWS R on the FMAs. With CWS engaged, the A/P manoeuvres the aeroplane in response to control pressures applied by either pilot. The control pressure is similar to that required for manual flight. When control pressure is released, the A/P holds existing attitude. Touch Control Steering (TCS) Touch Control Steering (TCS) also permits a pilot to manoeuvre their aircraft in pitch or roll, but unlike CWS the appropriate automatic control channels and servomotors are disengaged while the TCS button is held depressed allowing the pilot to fly the aircraft in the desired attitude using manual control. The autopilot control channels and servomotors are re-engaged by release of the TCS button and the autopilot continues to again hold the aircraft in the attitude in which it was left.

learning.explanation: The Radio Altimeter is a device capable of measuring the height of an aircraft above ground with a high degree of accuracy. Apart from providing a flight deck display of height above ground level (AGL), the radio altimeter has two other important functions: - It supplies the automatic flight system with data to affect automatic landings when used in association with the ILS/MLS. - It furnishes height information and rate of change of height to the Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS), and is a crucial component of this system. The autopilot is able to: - Sense changes in attitude. - Compute the amount and direction of control required. - Provide the muscle to move the control surfaces using servomotors. - Detect that the control has been applied and that the aircraft has responded. - Return control surfaces back to the neutral condition when the disturbance has been corrected. Before coupling an autopilot with the aircraft’s control system the integrity of the Autopilot Inner Loop must be established to ensure that it may safely take control of the aircraft. AUTOPILOT CONDITIONS OF ENGAGEMENT - INTERLOCKS (figure 2) Before an autopilot can safely engage with the flight controls, certain conditions must be fulfilled. These conditions vary slightly between autopilots, but take the form of a number of switches called interlocks, connected in series. A list of some of the conditions that must be operative before the interlocks allow autopilot engagement is as follows: - AC and DC power supplies in tolerance - Trimmed and erected gyroscopes - Yaw damper system engaged - Automatic pitch trim system available - Mach trim system available - Do not press instinctive Cut-Out (Disengage buttons) - Operative CADC - Stabilizer Trim Autopilot Cut-out Switch is at NORMAL. - Manual controls in their neutral position (i.e. Control wheel and column, turn knob, pitch switch). key_points: AUTOMATION Aircraft are equipped with several levels of automation, used to perform specific tasks
The appropriate use of automated systems significantly helps the flight crew with, for example: - Workload management - Situation awareness (traffic, ATC communication, etc
learning.explanation: AUTOMATION Aircraft are equipped with several levels of automation, used to perform specific tasks. The appropriate use of automated systems significantly helps the flight crew with, for example: - Workload management - Situation awareness (traffic, ATC communication, etc.). The flight crew must, at all times, perform both of the following: - Determine and select the appropriate level of automation that can include manual flight - Understand the operational effect of the selected level of automation. SITUATION AWARENESS (SAW) Situation Awareness (SAW) relates to a pilot’s ability to develop and maintain an accurate mental model of his/her operational status. This includes the aircraft’s position in time and space, its technical status, including the potential effects of any abnormalities, and the impact of environmental factors on present and future operations. CRM “CRM is the effective utilization of all available resources to achieve safe and efficient flight operations”. CRM is all about using resources to effectively manage two sources of risk in the operational environment: - THREATS to flight safety and - Human ERRORS THREAT AND ERROR MANAGEMENT(TEM) The Threat and Error Management (TEM) model is a conceptual framework for understanding operational performance. According to the TEM model, Threats, Errors, and Undesired Aircraft States (UAS) are everyday events that flight crews must manage to maintain safety. Aircraft Handling Errors Errors associated with the flight path and configuration of the aircraft (e.g.automation errors, mis-selections, incorrect speed, heading, altitude, etc.). ERROR MANAGEMENT AVOID – Use the protective mechanisms built into operational policies and procedures, as well as core competencies, to minimize the possibility of error (e.g. adhere to procedures, SOPs, briefings, etc.) TRAP – Recognize and correct errors, before they become cumulative or consequential, by proper crosschecking, monitoring, using checklists, etc. MITIGATE – Lessen the effect of errors that have not been avoided or trapped by changing your course of action e.g. going around, diverting, holding, etc.

learning.explanation: Most airliners are certified as multi-pilot aircraft. Generally, two pilots are required: a Captain and a First Officer. When in the plane, the Captain sits on the left-hand side and the First Officer sits on the right-hand side. Before each flight the crew agrees on which pilot will act as the Pilot Flying (PF) and which will act as the Pilot Monitoring (PM) for that particular flight. Each of them has a different area of responsibility in the cockpit. The Pilot Flying (PF) must concentrate on "flying the aircraft" to monitor and control the pitch attitude, bank angle, airspeed, thrust, sideslip, heading, etc., in order to achieve and maintain the desired targets, vertical flight path, and lateral flight path. The Pilot Monitoring (PM) must assist the PF and must actively monitor flight parameters, call out any excessive deviation and is responsible for radio communication with ATC, flight attendants, and passengers. Furthermore, he/she maintains the flight plan, monitors fuel, reads checklists, and operates the landing gear and flaps. Therefore, both flight crewmembers must: • Focus and concentrate on their tasks to ensure appropriate task sharing • Maintain situational awareness and immediately resolve any uncertainty as a crew.

key_points: Pilot Induced Oscillations (PIO), sometimes referred to as Pilot Involved Oscillations, are rare, unexpected, and unintended excursions in aircraft attitude and flight path caused by anomalous interactions between the pilot and the aircraft
Pilot Induced Oscillation events include a broad set of undesirable, and sometimes hazardous, phenomena that are associated with less than ideal interactions between pilots and aircraft

Pilot Induced Oscillations are sustained or uncontrollable oscillations resulting from efforts of the pilot to control the aircraft and occur when the pilot of an aircraft inadvertently commands an often increasing series of corrections in opposite directions; each one is an attempt to control the aircraft's reaction to the previous input with an overcorrection in the opposite direction
learning.explanation: Pilot Induced Oscillations (PIO), sometimes referred to as Pilot Involved Oscillations, are rare, unexpected, and unintended excursions in aircraft attitude and flight path caused by anomalous interactions between the pilot and the aircraft. Pilot Induced Oscillation events include a broad set of undesirable, and sometimes hazardous, phenomena that are associated with less than ideal interactions between pilots and aircraft. Pilot Induced Oscillations are sustained or uncontrollable oscillations resulting from efforts of the pilot to control the aircraft and occur when the pilot of an aircraft inadvertently commands an often increasing series of corrections in opposite directions; each one is an attempt to control the aircraft's reaction to the previous input with an overcorrection in the opposite direction. By definition, PIO (or APC) cannot happen unless the pilot is making inputs that are sustaining the oscillation. Consequently, the first and most critical step for exiting PIO is to get out of the loop. This presents three primary possibilities: - The pilot freezes the controls - The pilot releases the controls - The pilot significantly reduces the aggressiveness of control input

key_points: The basic principle of a closed-loop system is to measure a controlled variable, calculate the control error, and adjust the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error

The term "servomechanism" (sometimes shortened to "servo") could be defined as: An automatic device that uses error-sensing negative feedback to correct the performance of a mechanism and is defined by its function
In other words, a servo-system operates on the principle of using a some sort of detection device to automatically monitor the state of a particular system or a component (parameters, position, etc
learning.explanation: The basic principle of a closed-loop system is to measure a controlled variable, calculate the control error, and adjust the controlled variable to reduce/remove the control error. The term "servomechanism" (sometimes shortened to "servo") could be defined as: An automatic device that uses error-sensing negative feedback to correct the performance of a mechanism and is defined by its function. In other words, a servo-system operates on the principle of using a some sort of detection device to automatically monitor the state of a particular system or a component (parameters, position, etc.). Any difference between the detected values and desired values is treated as an error condition. In such cases the difference value (error signal) is amplified and then used by the corrective mechanism (e.g. an electric motor) to drive the system in the direction necessary to reduce or eliminate the error. Servos are frequently used in the position control systems. They are typically electrical or partially electronic in nature, using an electric motor as the primary means of creating the mechanical corrective force. Other types of servos use hydraulics, pneumatics, or magnetic principles. In aircraft systems, we can usually find servo-mechanisms in the autopilot systems (e.g. position control of the respective flight control surfaces), instruments (e.g. maintaining the vertical of a gyroscope), etc. Note: if you still have difficulties grasping the understanding of the principle behind a "servo" then let's take a look at two common car systems: • Electrically Controlled Car Windows: When you press the button to move the car window up or down, an electric motor is operated to move the actual window pane. Is this another example of a servo-system? No, because the action (e.g. motor opening the window) was based on a manual user input => you had to press the "open" button to get that window down. • Car Cruise Control System: You are driving down the highway and you set your cruise control at 130 km/h (desired state). The highway starts to go uphill suddenly and your cruise control system immediately detects the speed starting to decrease (detection mechanism). In other words, an error occurred - there is a difference between the desired and actually detected states. The system, therefore, applies a force to eliminate this error => the cruise control system adds more gas to compensate for the uphill terrain and brings the speed back up to the preselected usually so quickly the driver doesn't even notice any speed drop. Is this an example of a servo system? Of course, it is - we have an automatic error detection + error correction.

learning.explanation: Most airliners are certified as multi-pilot aircraft. Generally, two pilots are required: a Captain and a First Officer. When in the plane, the Captain sits on the left-hand side and the First Officer sits on the right-hand side. Before each flight the crew agrees on which pilot will act as the Pilot Flying (PF) and which will act as the Pilot Monitoring (PM) for that particular flight. Each of them has a different area of responsibility in the cockpit. The Pilot Flying (PF) must concentrate on "flying the aircraft" to monitor and control the pitch attitude, bank angle, airspeed, thrust, sideslip, heading, etc., in order to achieve and maintain the desired targets, vertical flight path, and lateral flight path. The Pilot Monitoring (PM) must assist the PF and must actively monitor flight parameters, call out any excessive deviation and is responsible for radio communication with ATC, flight attendants, and passengers. Furthermore, he/she maintains the flight plan, monitors fuel, reads checklists, and operates the landing gear and flaps. Therefore, both flight crewmembers must: • Focus and concentrate on their tasks to ensure appropriate task sharing • Maintain situational awareness and immediately resolve any uncertainty as a crew.

options.B: complete the automatic landing, including the landing roll-out to a full stop.
options.C: maintain safe flight, providing the autoland capability but without auto-flare.
options.D: complete the automatic landing, but unable to provide roll-out guidance.

key_points: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots or some part of the autoland system, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational

Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands
In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically
learning.explanation: In the event of a failure of one of the autopilots or some part of the autoland system, or if they deliver different control command outputs, the automatic landing system can behave in either of two ways: fail passive or fail operational. Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands. In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - The automatic landing system consists of three independent autopilot channels per controlled axis, it is capable of determining the failed component and excluding it from the computation. In the event of a failure, the approach, flare, and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system. Therefore, looking at each option: "maintain safe flight, but is unable to complete the automatic landing." Correct. Whilst the "maintain safe flight" is debatable, as the autopilot will eventually disconnect to allow the pilots to perform the landing manually or make a go-around, the fail passive system makes sure that there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, which you could consider to mean that it is safe flight, and the aircraft is not able to complete the autoland after such a problem. It is therefore most correct. "complete the automatic landing, including the landing roll-out to a full stop." The aircraft can no longer complete the automatic landing after a failure on a fail-passive system. "maintain safe flight, providing the autoland capability but without auto-flare." The autoland capability doesn't exist without auto-flare, and the autoland capability is gone when a fail-passive system has a failure of some kind. "complete the automatic landing, but unable to provide roll-out guidance." The aircraft can no longer complete the automatic landing after a failure on a fail-passive system.

content.question: You are in the cruise, preparing for an autoland, but you discover that the copilot's right windshield heating system is not functioning. Can you proceed with the autoland under these circumstances?

options.A: Yes, because the windshield heating system is not essential for the autoland procedure.
options.B: No, because autoland requires all aircraft systems to be fully operational.
options.C: Yes, as long as the weather conditions are clear, and there is no need for visibility enhancement.
options.D: No, unless approved by the airline's manuals and the Minimum Equipment List (MEL) procedures are followed.

key_points: Learning Objective 022
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 022.06.05.01.08: Describe how the failure of various systems, including systems not directly involved in the autoland process, can influence the ability to perform an autoland or affect the minima down to which the approach may be conducted. This is the third similar question about this topic we have in our database, and all appear to have quite significantly different options at least. Failure or malfunctions of any of the systems required to perform an automatic landing can result in a degradation of autoland performance. Additionally, systems which are not directly involved in the autoland sequency can also affect the ability to perform automatic landing and sometimes result in higher minima. Thus, the pilot must check the relevant manuals, such as the FCOM, QRH or MEL to verify whether the failure has any impact on the aircraft's approach capability. In case the defect causes a reduction in the aircraft's approach capability, a diversion or higher decision height and/or RVR might be necessary. Whilst I have never personally seen an aircraft or company procedure that requires windshield heating to be available for autoland, there are often requirements for windshield wipers to be operative, etc., as visual reference can be very important in the late stages of the approach and the landing. To go through each option: "Yes, because the windshield heating system is not essential for the autoland procedure." This is not necessarily always the case, and we cannot just assume that the windshield heating system is not a part of the required equipment. "No, because autoland requires all aircraft systems to be fully operational." Not always; the autoland has a certain amount of required equipment, but not everything is necessary. The specific requirements will be laid out in the company or aircraft manuals. "Yes, as long as the weather conditions are clear, and there is no need for visibility enhancement." Well the whole point of an autoland is an automatically flown approach and landing in poor visibility, so the weather conditions are not clear. "No, unless approved by the airline's manuals and the Minimum Equipment List (MEL) procedures are followed." Correct (mostly). We have to assume "no" until we find the list of required equipment for the autoland in the manuals, or reference documents such as the QRH for any restrictions caused by the loss of windshield heating. After checking these, only then can we perform the autoland if we are happy that it is allowed with such a defect. MEL procedures need not be followed as the problem has been found in the air, and MEL is a document used to check requirements before dispatch. Nonetheless, this is the most correct answer.

content.question: An autothrottle operating in SPEED mode (SPD) will…

options.A: Hold a fixed thrust, and the pilot has to adjust the speed using the manual flight controls.
options.B: Hold a fixed thrust, and the pilot must control the speed by using the trim.
options.C: Hold a fixed vertical speed.
options.D: Hold a selected airspeed.

key_points: The Autothrust computer interfaces directly with the engine computer, referred to as the FADEC
There are two parameters that an A/T can maintain, or try to attain: speed and thrust
In SPEED MODE [IAS/Mach Hold (SPD)] the throttle is positioned to attain a set target speed
learning.explanation: The Autothrust computer interfaces directly with the engine computer, referred to as the FADEC. There are two parameters that an A/T can maintain, or try to attain: speed and thrust. In SPEED MODE [IAS/Mach Hold (SPD)] the throttle is positioned to attain a set target speed. This function maintains a selected Indicated Airspeed (IAS) or Mach Number by comparing the chosen value with the actual value obtained from the Air Data Computer (ADC). It adjusts the aircraft's pitch, either up or down, to decrease or increase the aircraft's speed accordingly. In the THRUST MODE the engine is maintained at a fixed power setting according to the different flight phases. For example, during take-off, the A/T maintains constant take-off power until takeoff mode is finished.

content.question: The following can be displayed by a Flight Director (FD)...

options.A: Terrain avoidance warnings.
options.B: Pitch limits for TCAS RA.
options.C: Commands for capturing and maintaining the glide slope.
options.D: A trend arrow indicating speed development.

key_points: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude
Flight director information supplied by an FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI)
The vertical command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the bank angle of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The flight directors provide information for the pilot to join a desired path with the optimum attitude. Flight director information supplied by an FD computer is presented in the form of command bars on the Attitude Director Indicator (ADI). The vertical command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the bank angle of the aircraft. The vertical bar is always associated with the roll channel. The horizontal command bar of the FD supplies information about the direction and magnitude of the corrections to be applied to the pitch angle of the aircraft. The horizontal bar is always associated with the pitch channel. When tracking the glideslope, the command bars will indicate at which angle you should pitch and bank the aircraft in order to get back on the glideslope. In other words, it will indicate the correction to be applied to the pitch and bank angle in order to capture and then readapt this pitch and bank angle so that you follow the glideslope.

Capture phase The aircraft will follow a predefined rate of change of trajectory to achieve the new parameter without overshooting/undershooting. Tracking or hold phase The aircraft will maintain the set parameter until a new change has been initiated.

learning.explanation: Autopilot disengagement options Normal autopilot disengagement can be accomplished via a disengagement lever/button on the autopilot control panel. Pushing the TOGA switch with a single AP configuration. Moving the pitch trim wheel (this applies to some aircraft only).

content.question:
You are the PM of a commercial jet airliner flying an ILS CATIIIB approach in fail-operational status. If, at 70 feet RA, the G/S indication dissapears, can you continue the approach? What would the operational state be? If there's a warning, what type of warning would you get?
Alert height: 100 ft
RVR: 75 m

options.A: The crew receives a warning and the approach may be continued in fail-operational status.
options.B: The crew receives a caution alert and the approach cannot be continued because the FLARE mode would not engage.
options.C: The crew receives a warning and a go-around must be made.

key_points: LO 022
learning.explanation: LO 022.06.05.01.07: Describe typical failures that, if occurring below the alert height, will trigger a warning: all autopilots disengage; loss of ILS signal or components thereof; excessive ILS deviations; radio-altimeter failure. The Fail-Operational Automatic Landing System A fail-operational automatic landing system is defined as the capability of a system to withstand a failure without affecting the overall functioning of the system and without causing degradation of performance beyond the limits required for an automatic landing. The system requires a minimum of three autopilots. Alert Height The alert height is a specified radio altimeter height, based on the characteristics of the aircraft and its fail operational landing system. In operational use, if a failure occurred above the alert height in one of the required redundant operational systems in the aircraft, the approach would be discontinued, and a go-around executed unless reversion to a higher decision height is possible. If a failure in one of the required redundant operational systems occurred below the alert height, it would be ignored, and the approach would be continued to complete the autoland. If below the alert height all autopilots disengage, the ILS signal or components are lost, excessive ILS deviations occur, or the radio-altimeter fails, a warning will be triggered and an autoland procedure will not be possible. Fail passive - The automatic landing system is fed by only two fail-safe autopilots comparing their computations, therefore it cannot determine which one of the units is delivering the correct steering commands. In the event of a failure, there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude, but the landing is not completed automatically. Fail operational - The automatic landing system consists of three independent autopilot channels per controlled axis, it is capable of determining the failed component and excluding it from the computation. In the event of a failure, the approach, flare, and landing can be completed by the remaining part of the automatic system.

For example, when the pilot engages the CWS of a conventional autopilot and carries out a maneuver in roll, when the control wheel is released, the autopilot will maintain the flight attitude obtained at that moment

For example, when the pilot engages the CWS of a conventional autopilot and carries out a maneuver in roll, when the control wheel is released, the autopilot will maintain the flight attitude obtained at that moment.

content.question:
Considering vertical modes of the flight guidance system. What is the appropriate description of the following two vertical modes?
Vertical Speed (V/S)
Flight-Path Angle (FPA)

options.A: V/S will maintain a rate of climb or descent as set by the pilot while FPA will maintain a flight-path angle as coded in the FMS.
options.B: Both modes will make the aeroplane maintain a selected vertical speed, which varies with the airspeed to maintain a constant flight-path angle.
options.C: Both modes will make the aeroplane follow a trajectory where V/S uses feet per minute as reference and FPA uses an angle.
options.D: V/S will maintain a selected airspeed during the climb or descent and FPA will maintain a selected geometric flight-path angle during climb or descent.

key_points: The V/S - FPA mode is a selected mode
It acquires and holds the vertical speed or the flight path angle displayed in the V/S - FPA window of the FCU

The HDG V/S -TRK FPA pb on the FCU allows the flight crew to select either type of reference to be used for guidance and for display on the PFD (figure 1) The FMGC pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S or FPA
learning.explanation: The V/S - FPA mode is a selected mode. It acquires and holds the vertical speed or the flight path angle displayed in the V/S - FPA window of the FCU. The HDG V/S -TRK FPA pb on the FCU allows the flight crew to select either type of reference to be used for guidance and for display on the PFD (figure 1) The FMGC pitch mode guides the aircraft to the target V/S or FPA. The corresponding A/THR mode is SPEED or MACH. The V/S (FPA) guidance has priority over the speed guidance. If the selected target V/S or FPA is too high (relative to the current thrust condition and speed), the FMGC will steer the aircraft to the target V/S or FPA, but the aircraft will also accelerate or decelerate. VERTICAL SPEED An aircraft's vertical speed is the positive or negative rate of altitude change with respect to time. This is usually expressed in feet per minute (ft/min). The Vertical Speed in an aircraft is indicated with a vertical speed indicator (VSI) or instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI). FLIGHT PATH ANGLE (figure 2) The Flight Path Angle is the angle between the Aircraft’s Velocity Vector and the Horizon. If you are flying in a level flight your Flight Path Angle will be zero (over the horizon), regardless of the Pitch Angle. During a descent, the Flight Path Angle will be negative (below the horizon) thus when climbing the Flight Path Angle will be positive (over the horizon). content.question: The ADC fails. What happens to the A/P?

options.A: The A/P is affected and gets less accurate and thus more unreliable.
options.B: The A/P can be affected but it is still reliable and accurate enough.
options.C: The A/P is not affected as it doesn’t receive any ADC information.
options.D: The ADC supplies data only to the IRS and the FMS.

key_points: The Air Data Computer (ADC) collects all relevant air data, automatically eliminates the position errors of its individual sensors, computes the required output parameters and provides them to as many systems as desired
Possible inputs include status pressure (static ports), total pressure (pitot tubes), total air temperature (Rosemount probes) and angle of attack (sensors)
The ADC does not have an output device of its own
learning.explanation: The Air Data Computer (ADC) collects all relevant air data, automatically eliminates the position errors of its individual sensors, computes the required output parameters and provides them to as many systems as desired. Possible inputs include status pressure (static ports), total pressure (pitot tubes), total air temperature (Rosemount probes) and angle of attack (sensors). The ADC does not have an output device of its own. Instead, its computations are displayed on the barometric altimeter, vertical speed indicator, airspeed indicator and Machmeter. Any malfunction of an ADC affects all of these instruments. All of these outputs are used by the autopilot system to measure control inputs and deflection, therefore an ADC failure would have a great impact on the autopilot's precision and reliability.

content.question:
Concerning the FMS, the parameters used to work out the vertical flight profile are:
1 – zero fuel weight
2 – cost index
3 – fuel quantity
4 – oxygen quantity available for flight crew
5 – minimum safe enroute altitude
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The FMS vertical navigation management is generally performed based on the baro altitude input from the ADC

The parameters used by the FMS to compute the vertical flight profile are the: Zero fuel weight – the weight of the aircraft is crucial to provide the correct fuel predictions, constraints compliance, cruise levels, etc
Cost index - it is used to adapt the flight path of the aircraft for a given leg by finding a compromise between the fuel cost and the operating cost
learning.explanation: The FMS vertical navigation management is generally performed based on the baro altitude input from the ADC. The parameters used by the FMS to compute the vertical flight profile are the: Zero fuel weight – the weight of the aircraft is crucial to provide the correct fuel predictions, constraints compliance, cruise levels, etc. Cost index - it is used to adapt the flight path of the aircraft for a given leg by finding a compromise between the fuel cost and the operating cost. Fuel quantity – without fuel quantity information, the FMS cannot calculate much and provide an optimum flight path. Based on the above parameters, the FMS vertical navigation can output either a flight path angle or a speed target, complying with the selected AP/FD modes.

content.question: Which statement is true about the navigational database of a FMS?

options.A: Crew created navigational data may be saved in additional space in the database.
options.B: Crew-inserted navigational data is deleted automatically after each flight.
options.C: The navigational database is write-protected and it is not possible to otherwise save crew created navigational data.
options.D: The crew can overwrite existing database-data in the navigational database.

key_points: It shows the interface of an A320 FMS, including supplemental navigation data insertion and storage
The navigation database cannot be modified; however, it has some additional storage space where the flight crew can create and store additional waypoints, routes, navaids, etc
they might need along their route
learning.explanation: It shows the interface of an A320 FMS, including supplemental navigation data insertion and storage. The navigation database cannot be modified; however, it has some additional storage space where the flight crew can create and store additional waypoints, routes, navaids, etc. they might need along their route. An example of an additional waypoint could be some Decision Points, which coordinates are indicated in the Operational Flight Plan the crew receives during the briefing. On a several sectors day, it is very common that the pilot stores the flight back (the second sector) on this additional storage of the navigation database. For instance, the FMS2 Honeywell Release 1A, allows the flight crew to create and store up to 99 waypoints, 10 runways, 20 navaids, and 5 routes. This will be different from one FMS to another, but it already gives you an idea of the capability of the additional storage space of the navigation database, called the supplemental navigation database. Caution! It is really important to understand and make the difference that pilots can use the Supplemental Navigation database to write and read information => by adding their own customized waypoint or other navigation data. BUT this is limited to ONLY this Supplemental Nav database! At the time of the Main Nav database update (every 28 days) the Supp Nav database is automatically erased. It makes sense as the Supp Nav database could include waypoints that have been defined using waypoints contained in the Main Nav database that may have changed as a result of the update.

content.question: What is the first thing a crew working for an airline with a mixed fleet should check on the FMC before flying back to home base?

options.A: The weight and balance data in the FMC.
options.B: The aircraft type, engines, and databases in the FMC.
options.C: The fuel level and consumption data in the FMC.
options.D: The flight plan and route are programmed in the FMC.

key_points: The information stored in the FMC is called its database
The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation
The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model
learning.explanation: The information stored in the FMC is called its database. The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation. The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model. The data stored in the database includes aircraft drag and engine characteristics, maximum and minimum speeds. Generally, in the cockpit preparation phase and before starting to program the FMGS, the pilots will check both databases: - The performance database is checked by confirming the engine and aircraft type as well as the performance factor. - The navigation database validity is checked by confirming the current day is within the validity interval. If any of these databases are wrong (wrong engine/aircraft or validity expired) an authorised mechanic has to change it to the correct one.

content.question: The FMS Cost Index is used to adapt the…

options.A: Specific Fuel Consumption to the fuel density.
options.B: Flight path to the direct operating cost.
options.C: Performance index to the actual wind.
options.D: Take-off thrust to the Outside Air Temperature.

key_points: The Cost Index is used to adapt the flight path of the aircraft for a given leg by finding a compromise between the fuel cost and the operating cost
It is computed as follows: Aircraft operating cost ÷ Fuel cost Low CI (zero) – maximum range speed, resulting in minimum trip fuel
High CI – high airspeed, resulting in high fuel consumption
learning.explanation: The Cost Index is used to adapt the flight path of the aircraft for a given leg by finding a compromise between the fuel cost and the operating cost. It is computed as follows: Aircraft operating cost ÷ Fuel cost Low CI (zero) – maximum range speed, resulting in minimum trip fuel. High CI – high airspeed, resulting in high fuel consumption.

content.question:
A FMS can correct its fuel computations for the following non-standard configurations:
1 – landing gear down
2 – speed brakes extended
3 – one engine out
4 – slats / flaps not fully retracted
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory
The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing several extremely useful functions
One of those functions is the aid for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance
learning.explanation: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory. The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing several extremely useful functions. One of those functions is the aid for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance. This function will basically make internal calculations based on the aircraft weight, its cruising level, and the actual and expected wind conditions en-route to estimate the remaining fuel quantity along the flight plan. Most of the time this tool is very accurate, but the number of parameters influencing the fuel consumption makes it difficult to exactly predict the fuel consumption. That’s why you always need to do fuel checks at regular intervals during the flight and check that the fuel consumption is normal, the remaining fuel to destination is still the same, and there’s no leak. The FMS has also the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration. This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions.

content.question: Which Flight Management System databases are typically loadable?

options.A: The navigation database and the user database.
options.B: The performance database and the user database.
options.C: The navigation database and the performance database.
options.D: The navigation database and the operating system.

key_points: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary loadable components for the FMC to be operative
The performance data base includes aircraft’s drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path
The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow
learning.explanation: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary loadable components for the FMC to be operative. The performance data base includes aircraft’s drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path. The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow. The navigation data base of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav data base is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports Navaids Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.

content.question: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) position is…

options.A: the same as that given on the No.1 IRS.
options.B: the computed position based on a number of sources, e.g. IRS, VOR/DME, ILS and GPS.
options.C: the actual position of the aircraft at any point in time.

key_points: 226741: The FMS computed position along the flight plan is derived from the data provided by the IRS, DME, VOR, GPS, and ILS

learning.explanation: Control and Display unit (CDU) is an unit for FMS operation providing knobs and pushbuttons to enter data as well as a display to monitor flight progress. For a dual FMS architecture, two identical, independent CDUs provide the means for the flight crew to communicate with the FMC. The crew may enter data into the FMC using either CDU, although simultaneous entries should be avoided. The same FMC data and computations are available on both CDUs; however, each pilot has control over what is displayed on the individual CDU. key_points: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link
These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC)

The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link. These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC). The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance. The FMC and associated databases are an essential part of modern airline avionics. An FMC typically contains three databases in addition to the basic operational flight program (OFP). The first is a software options database which activates the optional functionality contained in the OFP that is desired by the operator. The second is the model and engine performance database and contains all the aircraft performance data which allows the FMC to compute fuel burn, optimum altitudes and airspeeds, etc. The third is the Navigation Database (NDB). The NDB is contains all the information required for building a flight plan and processing that plan when airborne. All these databases are stored in the FMC on an electrically erasable programmable read-only memory (EEPROM) card. Each of these databases can be updated via a data loader every 28 days. AIRAC updated every 28 days contains read only data but the pilot is still able to enter fixes, phantom stations and adjust parameters according to how he needs it within certain limits The NDB contains terminal and en route fixes; waypoints and navigation reference system (NRS) grid points; intersections; airways and radio navigation aids. It also contains airports; runways; STAR and SID; holding patterns; and instrument approaches such as VOR, non-directional beacon, area navigation (RNAV), required navigation performance (RNP), satellite based navigation system (SBAS), and ground based navigation system (GBAS).

learning.explanation: The fuel prediction logic of the FMS is predicated on the aircraft being in what is considered to be the “normal” configuration for the phase of flight. However, under circumstances of Abnormal Aircraft Configuration, such as slats not retracting, the fuel predictions are no longer accurate. Failure to realize this situation has lead crews to make false assumptions about their range and endurance and has been a contributory cause factor in several accidents and incidents. The ETA prediction is calculated based on groundspeed and distance from the active waypoint, therefore it will not be affected.

learning.explanation: POLAR NAVIGATION In the polar region, magnetic heading is unreliable or totally useless for navigation. Magnetic variations typically are extreme, often are not constant at the same point, and change rapidly as an airplane changes position. Flight crews must ensure that the computer flight plan shows true tracks and headings. If an active route takes an airplane over a pole, the preferred mode is lateral navigation (LNAV) with the autopilot engaged. content.question: What can be expected when there's a complete loss of GPS signal?

options.A: Loss of radio navigation signals.
options.B: Loss of integrity monitoring (RAIM) and RNP APCH capability.
options.C: Position uncertainty due to ND units shutdown.
options.D: Calculated position deviation.

key_points: GPS POSITION The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position
Each IRS computes a mixed IRS/GPS position called the GPIRS position
For this, each IRS can independently select their GPS source in order to maximize the availability of GPS data
learning.explanation: GPS POSITION The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position. Each IRS computes a mixed IRS/GPS position called the GPIRS position. For this, each IRS can independently select their GPS source in order to maximize the availability of GPS data. If the GPIRS data does not comply with an integrity criterion that is based on a Horizontal Integrity Limit (HIL) and on the automatic detection of failed satellites, the FMS rejects the GPS mode and uses the radio position update. The flight crew can deselect/select the GPS position on the SELECTED NAVAIDS page, if necessary. Without GPS PRIMARY (GPS deselected or inoperative) the navigation accuracy is lower and is a function of ground radio navaid infrastructure or elapsed time since the last radio update. RNAV(GNSS) approaches may be performed, provided GPS PRIMARY is available and with AP or FD engaged. The flight crew may check the position computation using the POSITION MONITOR page. RAIM Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitor (RAIM) is a form of integrity monitoring performed within the avionics themselves. It ensures available satellite signals meet the integrity requirements for a given phase of flight. By comparing the distance measurements of a number of satellites, the RAIM function can identify a satellite failure and issue an alert to the pilot. Without RAIM capability, the pilot has no assurance of the accuracy of the GPS position. A minimum of five satellites is required to detect a bad satellite; at least six satellites are required to detect and exclude a bad satellite from the navigation solution if your receiver has a fault detection and exclusion (FDE) RAIM algorithm.

With regard to a dual Flight Management System (FMS), which statement is correct?
FMC = Flight Management Computer

options.A: In `Dual Mode` both FMCs independently process the pilots` inputs, there is zero cross-checking between the FMCs.
options.B: Both FMS independently process the respective pilot’s inputs in “dual mode”, and cross-checking between them does not occur.

key_points: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions)
In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave
Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus
learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

learning.explanation: 022.05.01.01.06: State that in modern aircraft fitted with inertial reference system (IRS) and flight management system (FMS), the flight management computer (FMC) position is normally derived from a mathematical analysis of IRS, global positioning system (GPS), and distance measuring equipment (DME) data, VHF omnidirectional radio range (VOR) and LOC. The FMS uses a position that is a combination of the IRS position, GPS position and radio position (auto-tuning ground nav-aids). The FMS selects the best-calculated position based on a figure of merit and priority, called a Kalman Filter. For instance, GPS is the most accurate indication of position, so is usually the main input, but when that is no longer accurate enough, the FMS has to use the IRS and radio position, also depending on their current availability. Of course, IRS position is the most available data, as it does not require external information, but radio position is often more accurate, when available. The FMC determines and updates present aircraft position from the following systems: Loran – C (LOC) DME IRS GPS

learning.explanation: The FMS uses a position that is a combination of the IRS position, GPS position and radio position (auto-tuning ground nav-aids). The FMS selects the best-calculated position based on a figure of merit and priority, called a Kalman Filter. For instance, GPS is the most accurate indication of position, so is usually the main input, but when that is no longer accurate enough, the FMS has to use the IRS and radio position, also depending on their current availability. Of course, IRS position is the most available data, as it does not require external information, but radio position is often more accurate, when available. Modern FMS systems are very clever, and can automatically deselect GPS inputs if they become erroneous or lose signal, however, this is detrimental to the accuracy of the system, and will then have to use less accurate position data. This means that the aircraft may have a different position to what is calculated by the FMS, due to this lack of accuracy. learning.explanation: Aircraft designed to be operated by two pilots usually incorporate two FMS units. In such cases, both systems work independently from each other. Each of these systems consists of a separate flight management computer (FMC) as its core piece, and its own input/output device, the CDU or MCDU. Both systems are usually interconnected in a way that allows pilot entries made in one system to be transferred to the other unit. If one unit fails, the other FMS unit can still operate in “independent mode”, which provides less precision. In this architecture (dual FMS), a malfunction of the cross-talk bus may occur, where both FMS units will continue fully operational, as they perform all computations based on separate data. However, automatic alerts in the event of deviations between both units can no longer be issued, meaning that pilots will have to verify correct functions themselves. The exchange function between both units is also lost, therefore entries have to be made to both systems separately.

key_points: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions)
In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave
Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus
learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

learning.explanation: The flight management system (FMS) aids the flight crew in managing automatic navigation, in–flight performance optimization, fuel monitoring, and flight deck displays. Automatic flight functions manage the airplane lateral flight path and vertical flight path. The displays include a map for airplane orientation and command markers (bugs) on the airspeed and N1 indicators to assist in flying efficient profiles. The flight crew enters the desired route and flight data into the CDUs. The FMS then uses its navigation database, airplane position and supporting system data to calculate commands for manual or automatic flight path control. The FMS can automatically tune the navigation radios and determine lateral flight path courses. The FMS navigation database provides the necessary data to fly routes, SIDs, STARs, holding patterns, and procedure turns. Lateral offsets from the programmed route can be calculated and commanded. learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). key_points: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link
These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC)

learning.explanation: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link. These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC). The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance. The FMC and associated databases are an essential part of modern airline avionics. An FMC typically contains three databases in addition to the basic operational flight program (OFP). The first is a software options database which activates the optional functionality contained in the OFP that is desired by the operator. The second is the model and engine performance database and contains all the aircraft performance data which allows the FMC to compute fuel burn, optimum altitudes and airspeeds, etc. The third is the navigation database (NDB). The NDB contains all the information required for building a flight plan and processing that plan when airborne. All these databases are stored in the FMC on an electrically erasable programmable read-only memory (EEPROM) card. Each of these databases can be updated via a data loader. The NDB contains terminal and en route fixes; waypoints and navigation reference system (NRS) grid points; intersections; airways and radio navigation aids. It also contains airports; runways; STAR and SID; holding patterns; and instrument approaches such as VOR, non-directional beacon, area navigation (RNAV), required navigation performance (RNP), satellite based navigation system (SBAS), and ground based navigation system (GBAS). Note: Additional space is provided between the NDB to save navigational data created by the pilot

The (M)CDU provides the interface for pilots to input and manage data related to the flight plan, performance, and other functions. Modern aircraft are designed to maximize redundancy and minimize inconvenience. In the event of a failure of one (M)CDU, the other (M)CDUs can be used to communicate with either or both FMSs in dual mode. Bottom line is: In the event of a single FMS failure, the second system can operate the aircraft successfully in single mode, which will also activate automatically if the cross-talk bus connecting the FMSs in dual mode fails. However, if only a (M)CDU fails, the system can still remain in dual mode, but monitoring the system and making changes to the flight path would only be possible through the functional (M)CDU.

content.question: On a typical Navigation Display (ND) the current in-flight Wind Velocity (W/V) is displayed. Where is the W/V information derived from?

options.C: It is manually entered by the pilots, based on the latest information available.
options.D: It is entered into the FMC by either the pilots or dispatch/operations.

key_points: Navigation Display (ND) shows ‘instant’ wind velocity based upon on board computations are now quite accurate when instant variation is not required
Updating of on-board readouts of wind velocity depends on the system which generates them
FMS wind is the most accurate, because it is based upon changes of GPS or DME/DME position, but it may only be re-calculated every 30 seconds
learning.explanation: Navigation Display (ND) shows ‘instant’ wind velocity based upon on board computations are now quite accurate when instant variation is not required. Updating of on-board readouts of wind velocity depends on the system which generates them. FMS wind is the most accurate, because it is based upon changes of GPS or DME/DME position, but it may only be re-calculated every 30 seconds. The FMC (Flight Management Computer) is the box that calculates the wind. The inputs are: Track, heading and groundspeed from the nav system (varies between models, but typically inertial with updates from GPS and terrestrial navaids); and TAS from the ADC (Air Data Computer) The FMS solves for the final side of the vector triangle and computes wind (side 1- HDG/TAS; side 2- TRK/GS; side 3- Wind direction/magnitude). In a perfect world, the difference between TRK/GS and HDG/TAS is actual wind (direction, magnitude).

options.B: aeroplane performance and navigation.

key_points: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary components for the FMC to be operative
The performance database includes aircraft drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path
The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow
learning.explanation: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary components for the FMC to be operative. The performance database includes aircraft drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path. The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow. The navigation database of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav database is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports Navaids Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.
